triples.name: Epistemology
triples.relevance: The foundational discipline the paper contributes to by developing a new theory of justification.

triples.name: Justification (epistemology)
triples.relevance: The paper proposes a transformed scientific concept of justification that requires high probability and reveals error probabilities.

triples.name: Definitions of knowledge
triples.relevance: The paper builds on the justified true belief account of knowledge as its foundation.

triples.name: Foundationalism
triples.relevance: The paper proposes a foundation-theoretic epistemology that grounds beliefs through rational arguments rather than external authorities.

triples.name: Gettier problem
triples.relevance: The paper analyzes the Gettier paradox as evidence of tensions in commonsense intuitions about knowledge.

triples.name: Lottery paradox
triples.relevance: The paper uses the lottery paradox to demonstrate unsolvable tensions in commonsense knowledge intuitions.

triples.name: Deductive reasoning
triples.relevance: The paper discusses deduction as a form of justification that can convey certainty but whose scope is limited.

triples.name: Inductive reasoning
triples.relevance: The paper identifies induction as a necessary form of justification that can only convey high probability, not certainty.

triples.name: Abductive reasoning
triples.relevance: The paper identifies abduction as another form of justification beyond deduction that cannot convey certainty.

triples.name: Certainty
triples.relevance: The paper critiques the demand for certainty in justification as untenable and argues for high probability instead.
